## Floats

### Tables

```{r}
#| include: false

set.seed(1)
data <- data.frame(x = rnorm(30), y = rnorm(30))
```

Here is an example table (@tbl-example).

```{r}
#| label: tbl-example
#| tbl-cap: Table created with `knitr::kable()`
#| echo: false

knitr::kable(
  head(data, 2),
  digits = 2
)
```

### Figures

Below is an example figure created in R [@rcoreteamLanguageEnvironmentStatistical2025] (@fig-example).

```{r}
#| label: fig-example
#| fig-cap: Example R scatterplot.
#| fig-height: 3
#| fig-width: 7
#| echo: false

plot(data)
```

Sometimes you want to write a document in two-column mode. Those tend to look pretty nice. However what if you have a really wide table or figure? Here's what you can do to make the figure occupy the entire width of the page.

First, include
```yaml
functions: place
```
in the document's YAML.

Then, wrap your figure in a Quarto div[^fn0] like this:

```
::: {.place arguments='auto, scope: "parent", float: true'}
<Any content, e.g. code for drawing a figure>
:::
```

The above uses the Typst's `place()`[^fn1] function through the typst-function[^fn2] Quarto extension to place the div's content in `"parent"` scope (the document page is the column's parent) and must specify that Typst should treat the content as a float. The `auto` indicates where the figure should be on the page, and can be either auto, bottom, or top.

::: {.place arguments='auto, scope: "parent", float: true'}
```{r}
#| label: fig-2
#| fig-cap: A figure across columns.
#| fig-height: 3
#| fig-width: 7
#| echo: false

plot(data)
```
:::

Although this feels a bit hacky (it's less clean than something like a "`#| scope: parent`" chunk option, which would be nice), it doesn't affect other formats. Current Typst limitations can also lead the float to be placed below footnotes, as shown in this example.

[^fn0]: <https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html#sec-divs-and-spans>
[^fn1]: <https://typst.app/docs/reference/layout/place/>
[^fn2]: <https://github.com/christopherkenny/typst-function>

## Quarto markdown features

### Maths

LaTeX math notation is automatically converted to Typst and as such works just fine either inline ($y_i = \alpha + \beta x_i + \epsilon_i$) or in display mode (@eq-1):

$$
f(x \mid \mu, \sigma^2) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi \sigma^2}} \exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)
$$ {#eq-1}

### Block quotes

To insert a quote block, prepend a paragraph with `>`:

>A quote: "*Elit ullamcorper dignissim cras tincidunt lobortis feugiat vivamus at.*"

### Callouts

[Callout blocks](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/callouts.html), such as @tip-example, can be useful for highlighting content, such as one might do in a box that defines key terms, etc.

::: {#tip-example .callout-tip}
#### All kinds of markup
Markdown: `*italics*, **bold text**, ~subscript~, ^superscript^ & ~~strikethrough~~`

renders as

*italics*, **bold text**, ~subscript~, ^superscript^ & ~~strikethrough~~
:::

### Code listings

Code listings can also be cross-referenced (@lst-r).

```{r}
#| lst-label: lst-r
#| lst-cap: R code for pRos.
#| collapse: true

sqrt(1 + 1)
```
